thread.title: Week 4 injuries: Andrew Luck misses practice; Drew Brees likely; Luke Kuechly out
thread.title_full: Week 4 injuries: Andrew Luck misses practice; Drew Brees likely; Luke Kuechly out

title: Week 4 injuries: Andrew Luck misses practice; Drew Brees likely; Luke Kuechly out
text:
Colts QB Andrew Luck has never missed an NFL start. (Photo: Brian Spurlock, USA TODAY Sports)
15 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE INDIANAPOLIS — Indianapolis Colts quarterback Andrew Luck was not seen at practice Friday and is likely to be listed as questionable according to coach Chuck Pagano, who was nevertheless confident his franchise quarterback will play.
But for the second time in three days the Colts added a quarterback to the roster.
Josh Johnson, most recently with the New York Jets, was signed Friday (the team released cornerback Shaun Prater), giving them three quarterbacks on the active roster. Additionally, Alex Tanney, added on Tuesday, remains on the practice squad.
It raises further questions about starter Luck’s status with the Jacksonville Jaguars coming to town. Typically the Colts carry just two quarterbacks on the roster: Luck and backup Matt Hasselbeck. In light of Luck’s right shoulder injury — he’s been limited in practice all week — the Colts are making contingency plans for Sunday’s game against the Jacksonville Jaguars.
USA TODAY SPORTS WIRE
USA TODAY Sports' Week 4 NFL picks
Above all Luck has been dependable throughout his football career. Dating back to his college days, he’s made 86 consecutive starts. The last miss came December 31, 2009 – Luck’s freshman season at Stanford – after he underwent surgery on a finger on his throwing hand.
He’s made 57 straight starts to begin his NFL career – no small feat when you consider the offensive lines he’s played behind.
As for Hasselbeck, the 16-year veteran hasn’t made an NFL start in nearly three years. His last came with the Tennessee Titans on Nov. 12, 2012. Asked if he’d be ready if called upon, Hasselbeck didn’t flinch.
“That’s my job,” he said. “I need to do that. It’s one of the things required by my job. If necessary, I’ll be ready to go.”
On the other side, the Jags will be without receiver Marqise Lee (hamstring), right guard Brandon Linder (shoulder), defensive tackle Sen’Derrick Marks (knee) and running back Denard Robinson (knee). Tight end Julius Thomas (hand surgery) also is not ready to debut for his new team. However left tackle Luke Joeckel, safety Johnathan Cyprien and defensive end Andre Branch will return after missing games.
In other injury news Friday:
— After sitting out Week 3 with an injured throwing shoulder, New Orleans Saints QB Drew Brees is expected to play Sunday night against the Dallas Cowboys, according to coach Sean Payton. Brees, who'd never missed a Saints start due to injury, has practiced all week.
— A concussion will keep Carolina Panthers MLB Luke Kuechly out for the third consecutive game. WR Jerricho Cotchery (ankle) is also out against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers while RB Jonathan Stewart (tibia) and fullback Mike Tolbert (groin) practiced Friday and are listed as probable.
— Houston Texans RB Arian Foster (groin surgery) will be a game-time decision Sunday against the Atlanta Falcons. He has not played this year since injuring himself in training camp.
— Philadelphia Eagles RB DeMarco Murray, who missed Week 3 with a lingering hamstring issue, will be a game-time decision Sunday against the Washington Redskins on what is likely to be a wet field.
— As expected, the Buffalo Bills won't have RB LeSean McCoy (hamstring) or WR Sammy Watkins (calf). McCoy indicated he could be out until his injury fully heals.
— The Miami Dolphins could have an issue at tight end with Dion Sims (concussion) doubtful and Jordan Cameron (groin) questionable to face the New York Jets in London. Dolphins LT Branden Albert (hamstring) is also doubtful. The Jets will be without G Willie Colon (knee) and TE Jeff Cumberland (concussion) while WR Eric Decker (knee) is questionable. CBs Darrelle Revis (hamstring) and Antonio Cromartie (hip), LB David Harris (finger) and RB Chris Ivory (quadriceps) are expected to play.
Contributing: The Indianapolis Star's Zak Keefer

15. Raiders at Bears: Beyond checking in on Amari Cooper's progress, it's difficult to find a reason to watch this game. USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen 14. Browns at Chargers: Things are looking bleak in both Cleveland and San Diego after 1-2 starts. USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen 13. Jaguars at Colts: The Colts might not be out of their funk just yet, but the Jaguars will be hard-pressed to leave Indianapolis with a win. USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen 12. Texans at Falcons: Julio Jones is off to a record start for the Falcons, but the Texans throw the ball more than any other team. USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen 11. Panthers at Buccaneers: Quarterback showdowns don't get much better than the one we'll see Sunday between these two gunslingers. USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen 10. Giants at Bills: New York is coming off extra rest after last Thursday's win, but Buffalo is riding high following its win over Miami. USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen 9. Eagles at Redskins: Are the Eagles really fixed? Chip Kelly and Co. can get to .500 in this NFC East showdown. USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen 8. Rams at Cardinals: Carson Palmer hasn't been touched much this season, but he hasn't faced a defensive line like the Rams' front. USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen 7. Packers at 49ers: Aaron Rodgers and the Packers could make things ugly for a 49ers team that struggled to stop the Cardinals. USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen 6. Cowboys at Saints: Brandon Weeden and Luke McCown don't exactly scream prime-time matchup, but Sunday night's game has potential nonetheless. USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen 5. Ravens at Steelers: Thursday night's matchup gets a bit of a twist with Ben Roethlisberger sidelined. USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen 4. Chiefs at Bengals: The Chiefs' fearsome pass rush looks to rattle Andy Dalton and the 3-0 Bengals. USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen 3. Lions at Seahawks: Former Seahawks wide receiver Golden Tate will be looking for revenge against his former teammates. USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen 2. Jets at Dolphins: Make sure to get up early Sunday to catch this AFC East matchup in London. USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen 1. Vikings at Broncos: Denver's top-ranked defense faces another big test in Adrian Peterson. USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Like this topic?
